column7: and indivisible in the general effect. The proportionate weight of stringing has to be met by a proportionate thickness and barring of the sound-board
column8: and a proportionate thickness and elevation of the bridge.The tension of the strings is met by a framing
column9: which has become more rigid as the drawing power of the strings has been gradually increased. In the present concert grands of Messrs. Broadwood
column10: that drawing power may be stated as starting from 150 lb. for each single string in the treble
column11: and gradually increasing to about 300 lb. for each of the single strings in the bass. I will reserve for the historical description of my subject some notice of the different kinds of framing that have been introduced. It will suffice
column13: to say that it was at first of wood
column16: of wood and iron; in the present day the iron very much preponderating.
